Award.AwardTitle: Reconciling divergent histories of Eastern Pacific climate with new coral data from Galapagos (Ecuador)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The El Niño (ENSO) system orchestrates climate variability and extremes worldwide, and its behavior under greenhouse warming remains one of the largest uncertainties in anticipating future climate change. ENSO has a dramatic impact on the climate of the Galapagos Islands, and this impact is preserved in paleoclimate records from the archipelago. But published paleoclimate records from the Galapagos yield disagreeing versions of the islands' recent climate history, including the magnitude of recent warming and the range and timing of ENSO variability.

To resolve these disagreements, this project will develop reconstructions of regional sea surface temperature using the isotope geochemistry of long-lived, annually banded corals. With these records, which directly track ocean conditions, important questions about recent climate variability and change in this iconic region can be addressed. For example, is the Galapagos warming as fast as the rest of the world? What is the history of El Niño variability in the region? Do changes in this region coincide with periods of higher-latitude climate variability such as cooler ("Little Ice Age") conditions between 1500-1850? Understanding the full range of ENSO variability and ongoing trends is important locally, for improving conservation planning and climate adaptation efforts in the Galapagos National Park and Marine Protected Area. The results of the research will be useful across many disciplines, from conservation management in Galápagos to evaluation of global climate models. Funding also supports student education and training at the graduate and undergraduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The year-to-year climate variability across much of the world is orchestrated by changes in tropical Pacific sea surface temperature (SST) associated with the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon (ENSO). Since 1982, three massive ENSO warm events occurred in which unusually warm Pacific SST generated significant climatic, ecological, and societal impacts worldwide. Are these exceptional climate anomalies a harbinger of a stronger ENSO in a warmer world? Studies of past climate can reveal whether – and how – ENSO is changing as the world warms.

Our project explores the history of ENSO in the Galapagos islands, Ecuador. We have produced records of past ENSO variations using the geochemistry of coral skeletal material, which reflects the environmental conditions under which the coral grew (including temperature). Corals can grow for one or more centuries, at a rate of 10-20 mm/yr. We sample the coral skeleton from top to bottom at monthly (1mm) resolution over the past few centuries to produce long records of past climate; we can apply the same method to fossil corals that grew over more distant intervals. We measure primarily the Sr/Ca ratios and the relative abundance of oxygen isotopes – two well established methods for reconstructing past SST. This approach allows us to extend the record of ENSO back in time. In the Galápagos, observed SST data and coral records have both suggested that ENSO variations are strong and that global warming may be moderated by the influence of cool, upwelling water.

Here we focus on the past 600 years. Our reconstructed history of SST is still being finalized, but several points are clear:

-       Since 1940, we find statistically detectable warming in the northern archipelago, the home of the Galápagos’ only living reefs. Other studies have argued against strong warming in the Galapagos, but did not examine the northern islands. We suggest these reefs may be more vulnerable than previously thought to global warming.

-       We explored using other element-specific measures of past SST (Mg/Ca and Li/Mg ratios); we found that Sr/Ca ratios produce the highest quality SST record among these approaches, especially when Sr/Ca data are replicated across sites.

-       The strongest warm ENSO events are stressful for corals: our modern cores show a temporary death hiatus across the 1982-3 event, followed by regrowth some years later. These were among the minuscule proportion of Galápagos corals that survived that year. Another unusually warm event, in 1997-8, produced a persistent shift in aspects of the coral skeletal geochemistry.

-       Over the past 600 years, the most recent several decades exhibit the warmest SST and strong ENSO variability. However, previous centuries also display episodes of similarly strong ENSO variability.

-       Variations in the upwelling of nutrient-rich waters can be detected in the coral skeletal Ba/Ca ratio as measured by our particular methods, but only in the westernmost site where upwelling is strongest. A more sensitive method should be used in studies aiming to reconstruct past Galapagos upwelling from other sites.

-       Work is underway to put our new data together with other Pacific coral records and terrestrially based climate histories to produce a clearer picture of ENSO and its impacts over the past 600 years.

The corals of Galapagos preserve a unique history of regional climate change; they are also vulnerable to ENSO-related swings in local conditions and especially so as warming continues. We hope to use the cores we have collected to expand the scope of this study and explore past changes in ocean pH, coral calcification, and overall stress levels that lead to coral bleaching.
